raw_claims:
```json
{
    "claims": [
        {
            "claim_id": 1,
            "claim_text": "Large Language Models (LLMs) suffer from hallucinations, which means they lie and fabricate non-existent facts or inappropriate information.",
            "location": "Abstract",
            "claim_type": "Major claim",
            "exact_quote": "Large Language Models (LLMs), including GPT-3.5, LLaMA, and PaLM, seem to be knowledgeable and able to adapt to many tasks. However, we still can not completely trust their answer, since LLMs suffer from hallucination—fabricating non-existent facts to cheat users without perception."
        },
        {
            "claim_id": 2,
            "claim_text": "Hallucinations are not bugs, but features as adversarial examples.",
            "location": "Abstract",
            "claim_type": "Major claim",
            "exact_quote": "This phenomenon forces us to revisit that hallucination may be another view of adversarial examples, and it shares similar features with conventional adversarial examples as the basic feature of LLMs."
        },
        {
            "claim_id": 3,
            "claim_text": "The occurrence of hallucination is essentially finding similar corpus from the parameterized memorization to fabricate non-existent answers.",
            "location": "Introduction",
            "claim_type": "Minor claim",
            "exact_quote": "Unlike these, we discuss the hallucination phenomenon out of training data. We found that some non-sense Out-of-Distribution(OoD) prompts composed of random tokens can also elicit the LLMs responding hallucinations."
        },
        {
            "claim_id": 4,
            "claim_text": "Hallucinations share similar features with adversarial examples that the perturbed data perseveres the same semantics as the original clean ones, but models output mismatched answers.",
            "location": "Introduction",
            "claim_type": "Minor claim",
            "exact_quote": "Hallucinations shares similar features with adversarial examples that the perturbed data perseveres the same semantics as the original clean ones, but models output mismatched answers."
        },
        {
            "claim_id": 5,
            "claim_text": "We can trigger hallucinations via non-sense OoD prompts, which is far away from training dataset distributions.",
            "location": "Introduction",
            "claim_type": "Minor claim",
            "exact_quote": "Besides, our experiments explanation suggests a fundamental attribute of LLMs—it suffers from adversarial prompts leading to notorious and mismatched codswallop and hallucination."
        },
        {
            "claim_id": 6,
            "claim_text": "Hallucinations are responses that do not consist with human cognition and facts.",
            "location": "Section 2.1",
            "claim_type": "Major claim",
            "exact_quote": "Differently, human-being tend to reply with truthful fact, rather than fabricate nonsense or non-existent fake facts."
        },
        {
            "claim_id": 7,
            "claim_text": "We can automatically elicit the LLMs to fabricate non-existent facts or inappropriate information.",
            "location": "Section 3",
            "claim_type": "Major claim",
            "exact_quote": "We trigger the hallucinations from two opposing perspectives: i) selectively replace some tokens of the original sentence to preserve its semantic consistency; ii) construct non-sense OoD prompts composed of random tokens."
        },
        {
            "claim_id": 8,
            "claim_text": "We propose an automatic triggering method called hallucination attack, which includes two modes: weak semantic and OoD attacks.",
            "location": "Section 3",
            "claim_type": "Major claim",
            "exact_quote": "The former starts with a given semantic prompt. By selectively replacing a few tokens, we could construct an adversarial prompt to maintain its semantic consistency while triggering hallucinations."
        },
        {
            "claim_id": 9,
            "claim_text": "We can construct adversarial prompts to elicit the LLMs to generate pre-defined hallucinations.",
            "location": "Section 3",
            "claim_type": "Minor claim",
            "exact_quote": "In the following part of this section, we will introduce these four components in detail."
        },
        {
            "claim_id": 10,
            "claim_text": "We can trigger hallucinations via non-sense OoD prompts, which is far away from training dataset distributions.",
            "location": "Section 3",
            "claim_type": "Minor claim",
            "exact_quote": "On the other hand, we expect to investigate which tokens in the OoD prompt are the key to triggering hallucinations."
        },
        {
            "claim_id": 11,
            "claim_text": "We can trigger hallucinations via non-sense OoD prompts, which is far away from training dataset distributions.",
            "location": "Section 3",

            "exact_quote": "On the other hand, we expect to investigate which tokens in the OoD prompt are the key to triggering hallucinations."
